Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Understanding and Forecasting North Atlantic and US Landfalling Tropical Cyclone Activity and Associated Rainfall
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will advance our understanding of the physical processes responsible for the genesis, development and tracking of North Atlantic and US landfalling tropical cyclones (TCs). The team will apply newly gained physical insights towards the development of a seasonal forecasting system of North Atlantic and US landfalling TCs and associated rainfall. The approach follows in three phases: Phase I will focus on advancing the understanding of the physical processes responsible for the North Atlantic and US landfalling TC activity. Phase II will develop a seasonal forecasting system of TC activity using the knowledge established in Phase I. Phase III will focus on the seasonal forecast of rainfall associated with TCs during and after US landfall. The methodologies build on analysis tools and data sets that the PI and Co-PI have extensive experience with, and developed further here to address the problem of rainfall associated with landfalling TCs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research activity sought to: i) use observations, physical understanding of the climate system and dynamical models to improve the mechanistic understanding of the physical processes that control the genesis, development and tracks of hurricanes and tropical cyclones, with particular focus on U.S. landfall, and ii) apply this insight to developing and evaluating statistical and statistical-dynamical prediction methodologies for hurricanes and their associated rainfall over land. Throughout the research project a number of significant results were developed, and presented in peer-reviewed journal articles, presentations at national and international conferences, and incorporated into university classes. In addition, this work helped inform the development of experimental real-time seasonal prediction methodologies for hurricanes. During this work one graduate student, one postdoctoral researcher and one research specialist were mentored, and fully entrained in the research activities.

 

This work evaluated the response of hurricane rainfall, with a focus on rainfall over land, in a suite of global climate models to a set of idealized perturbations, in order to understand the sensitivity and mechanisms controlling tropical cyclone rainfall. This work also explored the observed relationship between tropical cyclone activity globally and rainfall and rainfall extremes over land, finding that tropical cyclones are a principal mechanism for the total annual rainfall and rainfall extremes in many places in the world (including the southeastern United States), even though at any given point are present but a short period of time (days in a year). Observational work and analysis of seasonal predictions with high-resolution models also identified the relationship of potentially predictable patterns of climate (such as the El Niño-Southern Oscillation phenomenon) with the tracks and rainfall of tropical cyclones; we also found that certain patterns with lower expected seasonal predictability (in particular the North Atlantic Oscillation) were an important control on observed and predicted hurricane tracks. Using observations and targeted perturbations with global dynamical models, this work showed that a recently identified pattern of climate variability in the central Pacific (the so called “Pacific Meridional Mode”) could impact hurricane activity in the Atlantic and typhoon activity in the western Pacific, and that climate variability in the Atlantic (the so called “Atlantic Meridional Mode”) could impact typhoon activity in the Pacific – emphasizing the interconnected nature of the global climate system and its impacts, and the need for a global focus in efforts to make seasonal predictions of regional phenomena.
